You can use Amazon CloudWatch Synthetics to create canaries, configurable scripts that run on a schedule, to monitor your endpoints and APIs. Canaries follow the same routes and perform the same actions as a customer, which makes it possible for you to continually verify your customer experience even when you don't have any customer traffic on your applications. IAM identity-based policies can be used to define permissions that grant read access to the DynamoDB table for unauthenticated or anonymous users. These policies can be attached to the IAM roles associated with the application's execution environment. By doing so, interactions with DynamoDB are secured, ensuring that only the necessary actions are allowed. It's important to note that the question does not mention any specific requirements for user authentication or authorization. Therefore, in this case, the most suitable AWS feature to meet the requirements is option A - IAM identity-based policy.

IAM identity-based policy

IAM policies are used to grant permissions to AWS services, resources and actions. The developer can use IAM policies to control access to the S3 bucket and DynamoDB table, in order to ensure that only authorized users can access the resources. The developer can also use IAM policies to control access to other AWS services that the application may interact with, such as AWS Lambda or Amazon SNS.
